pgTitle: List of World War II prisoner-of-war camps in the United States

rows.text: Kurt Rossmeisl escaped on 4 August 1945 and surrendered in 1959.
Two escaped. Used a railroad box car. Recaptured: Roanoke, Va.
University of Texas Health Science Center at Tyler
Largest all-new prisoner of war compound ever constructed on American soil. It is now used as United States Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS).
First attempted escape by two German POWs on 5 November 1942.
Little Kohler, Town of Fredonia, Wisconsin
The current site of the TriCity Airport (MBS)
Close to Fort Lincoln and held over 5,000 confederate soldiers
1942-1945: held Japanese-American internees, and then German and Italian POWs.
Constructed for prisoners, later reused for housing after the war
On site of Will Rogers World Airport, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma
Germany's "Great Escape" was from a -foot (m) tunnel by 25 prisoners on 24 December 1944.
Green Lakes State Park, New York
14 miles SE of Roswell, New Mexico
Camp Scott held more than 600 German POWs from the Afrika Korps from late 1944 until the camp closed in November 1945.
same commander as Camp Michaux camp

Camp Thomasville, Georgia. Large German pow camp 2 miles outside of Thomasville. Following WWII, the facilities were taken over by the Veterans Administration with both a hospital and large domiciliary complement. Facilities now serve as an adjunct to the state's mental health program.

A -foot (m) electrically-lighted escape tunnel was discovered by authorities. This was probably a coal mining tunnel in that Engleville was coal mining camp where this POW camp is purported to be located. Coal mining was prominent in the late 1870's to the 1950's. A few continued into the early 1970's in Las Animas county where Trinidad is located.
Reinhold Pabel escaped on 9 September 1945 and was recaptured in Chicago in March 1953
Between Farmington and Ste. Genevieve, Missouri
Now Tampa International Airport and Drew Park
Harry Girth escaped in June 1946 and surrendered to authorities in New York City in 1953.
A -foot (m) nearly-completed escape tunnel was discovered by authorities.
Oklahoma Grider Field, Pine Bluff Arkansas
Valley Forge General Hospital, later the Golf Course area
Windfall Indiana World War II POW Camp
